pros: Great support from co-workers, none from your bosses.
cons: No management support, would rather you didn't eat, let alone take a break. Your lunch hour (only half) will be spent working - so be good at juggling food and typing. Duties piled on top of duties and when you ask for help from your boss you are told that they are tryiing to hire people (this was before the pandemic). Those hired before your will be paid more than 15/hour while you get paid only 11.50 an hour for doing the same job. I understand giving pay raises but the hiring rate should go up not down and they pay less when getting hired in than they did ten years ago. Probably from the CEO stealing money. No oversight.

pros: co workers, my manager, the job I did helping others, health insurance was relativity cheap as long as you don't need to use it too much.

job_title: Mental Health Therapist in Toledo, OH
pros: The therapy and caseworker team work really well together and can consult on cases
cons: Because you're in the field, they'll use your desire to help people against you. When you say you're burned out, their hands are tied, when you want a raise, they don't have the money (but they definitely do). They'll basically force you to schedule appointments through lunch and through supervision and team meetings.

job_title: Former Burned Out Worker Bee in Toledo, OH
pros: Excellent working relationships with other employees
cons: They talk a good game, but the game is really about putting as many bodies through billable hours as possible. Helping people is a byproduct. They burn out their case managers rapidly, and work their direct care employees into the ground. If you're looking to be upper management you're golden.

pros: Great people to work with . They give you a chance to move up within the company.
cons: The pay is horrible. You build relationships with people who go on to overdose and that can become overwhelming .

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Toledo, OH
pros: Good Benefits:  Retirement Package/ 403 B , Roth IRA, insurance,  Medical Coverage, helping the Community, Saving Lives, Deputy Sheriff 's Security.
cons:
Location,  Understaffed, Supplies/equipment run out or are unavailable at times, Patients unable to reach a live person when contacting clinic, or it  takes them a long time to get to the right staff member.   Overcrowded Lobby,  lack of  enough vending machines,(we have 2 and they are always empty) or faulty machines  
No healthy snacks available for purchase to staff and clients.   Lack of Employee appreciation.

review_title: They throw hard workers away like garbage
pros: Insurance, coworkers, clients, and families
cons: Toxic, Stressful. They don't appreciate the hard work you put in. Micromanagement will be enough to make you go off the deep in. They care nothing about you just the bottom dollar. The type of license you have doesn't matter one bit. Dedication throw that out the door as well, they don't care. If you are a yes person, start as an intern & never leave you're good you will climb right on up the ladder I promise. You work hard they will kick you out faster than you walked in. Trust me just run.

pros: Depending on your supervisor hours can be flexible, benefits are inexpensive, that's about it. I can't even meet the 20 word minimum with the "pros" :(
cons: Lots of high level managers with high turnover. All high level positions are hired from outside without giving employees the chance to move up. High level managers often lack the experience you'd think you'd want, but they all seem to be in the right clique or play tennis with someone. The pay is insultingly low. 13.50$ for a bachelor level position? Communication across departments is very poor. We didn't get a bonus this year, but the company had plenty of money to hire multiple new positions for upper level management that seemed unnecessary. Agency is very top-heavy and doesn't take input from line staff. The list goes on but this is enough to give you insight to rethinking working here. Unless of course you're into tennis, then you'll make it to the top....

pros: Great doctors and nurses that really care for the clients,  fantastic coworkers, really good hours and work/life balance
cons: Pay way too low for positions that are supporting roles; lack of higher ups knowing we exist, what we do or how hard we work to give the best to the clients even though we may be “ behind the scene.”  Getting rid of great doctors of driving them away.

review_title: Change is the only constant in life - and it's the best thing that Zepf has done!
pros:
I’ve been working at Zepf for close to 2 years and have seen the agency go through an immense amount of change; both bad and good. 

With the new leadership changes that Zepf has experienced there is so much good to speak of. To start – open communication has been steadily increasing as time goes on, I’ve also seen the new employee on-boarding process get revamped by our new HR reps to become more intricate & actually beneficial for the new staff. I think one thing that I am most excited about is the fact that we are also in the works of implementing the sanctuary model to our culture, which is very reassuring for staff because it involves trauma informed CARE for staff, which is sometimes forgotten about as we are putting our clients first. Not to mention the other great things that Zepf offers; like innumerable amounts of training to increase our skills and also receive CEUs, the great coworkers, and simply the rewarding work we get to experience daily. 

The pay might not be the highest, which is understandable for being a non-profit, but they sure do make up for it with quite literally the cheapest benefits package that I’ve ever seen. I’ve never heard of a company offering family coverage for medical & dental insurance for ONLY $50!!

I think every person experiences some good and bad the agency, but after watching them progress for the almost two years – I’d say Zepf is in such a better place given that Zepf can only control so much of the outcomes (i.e. loss of funding).
cons:
Low pay (which is made up for in the great benefits) 
Loss of funding resulted in some scary/stressful thoughts for staff - I think we're in the works of recovering from that.

review_title: Not just mental health. Integrated care at its best.
pros: The flex time is unbeatable. Love that also focus on health and wellness. The integrated care module is like no other
cons: The pay is not comparable to the amount of work, stress and demands that are placed on their staff. They do not reward the staff who has been there and dedicated for long periods of time hard work is never recognized
